Speaker: shooting script
Dialogue: June 11, 1979 Revised 6/15/79

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No, but thank you very much.

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Jack, isn't that Fred Bliffert over there in the blue turtleneck? Maybe he's on our flight to Chicago.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah, I think he is.  Hey, Fred!

Speaker: elderly woman
Dialogue: Go, O.J., go!!

Speaker: security lady
Dialogue: Please put your metal objects on this tray.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: Taxi!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Back in a minute.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Elaine!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ted!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I came home early and found your note. I guess you meant for me to read it later. Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I just don't want to go over it any more.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I know things haven't been right for a long time, but it'll be different. If you'll just be patient, I can work things out.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I have been patient and I've tried to help, but you wouldn't even let me do that.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Don't you feel anything for me at all any more?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It takes so many things to make love last. Most of all it takes respect. And I can't live with a man I don't respect!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: What a pisser.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: This is Captain Oveur.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: I've got it!

Speaker: turnansky
Dialogue: There's a passenger on your Chicago flight two-oh-niner, a little girl named Lisa Davis -- en route to Minneapolis. She's scheduled for a heart transplant and we'd like you to tell her mother that we found a donor an hour ago.

Speaker: turnansky
Dialogue: We have the heart here ready for surgery and we must have the recipient on the operating table within six hours.

Speaker: turnansky
Dialogue: I want you to make sure she is kept in a reclined position and that a continuous watch is kept on her I.V.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: All right. Give me Hamm on five, hold the Mayo.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Look, you'll be back in town tomorrow night. We'll have dinner -- talk it over.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I won't be back. I've requested the Atlanta run.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Elaine, not yet. I promise you I really can change.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Then why don't you take the job that Louie Netz offered you at Boeing?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: You know I haven't been able to get near an airplane since the war. And even if I could, they wouldn't hire me because of my war record.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Your war record? You're the only one keeping that alive. For everyone else it's ancient history.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: You expect me to believe that?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It's the truth. What's hurt you the most is your record since the war. Different cities, different jobs, and not one of them shows you can accept any real responsibility.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: But if you'll just give me...

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It's too late, Ted. When I get back to Chicago, I'm going to start my life all over again. I'm sorry.

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: Any word on that storm lifting over Salt Lake, Clarence?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Unlikely, Victor. I just reviewed the Area Report for 1609 hours through 2400 hours. That's an occluded front stalled over the Dakotas -- backed up all the way to Utah.

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: If it decides to push over into the Great Lakes it could get plenty soupy. How about the southern route, around Tulsa?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: I double checked the terminal forecast and winds aloft. IFR ceilings all the way.

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: Where do they top out?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Well, there's some light scattered cover at twenty thousand with icing around eighteen.

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: Looks like the original flight plan over Denver is still the best bet.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Denver it is.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Sorry, Clarence. Latest weather report shows everything socked in from Salt Lake to Lincoln.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Hi, Roger. Good to have you aboard. Victor, this is Roger Murdock.

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: How do you do, Roger?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What did you think of 'Great Expectations?'

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Well, it wasn't all that I had hoped.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Oh, Bill, I'm going to miss you so much.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: You promise you'll write.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Every day.

Speaker: airport steward
Dialogue: Better get on board, son.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Can you tell me if Elaine Dickinson is on this flight?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I'd like one ticket to Chicago. No baggage!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Smoking, please.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Fourteen-B. It's halfway down on your right.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: No. I've been nervous lots of times. I used to be a pilot myself...during the war.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: We'll be taking off real soon so we better fasten you in tight.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Thank you. Oh Mother, this is so exciting.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: That's good advice. You relax and I'll be back after we take off.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Two-zero-niner to ground control. We are loaded and ready to taxi.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Good-bye, darling.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Oh, good-bye, Bill! Have your picture taken as soon as you get there and send me one!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Don't you go getting fat or anything.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Don't worry, I won't. Okay, here -- hurry!

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Oh, but it's your watch. You shouldn't. You'll need it.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Good-bye, darling.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Good-bye, darling.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Good-bye, darling.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Roger.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Roger.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: basta
Dialogue: Request vector...over.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: We have clearance, Clarence.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Roger, Roger. What's our vector, Victor?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Do you feel all right, sir?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Oh -- I haven't flown for a long time.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Would you like something to read?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: How about this leaflet: 'Famous Jewish Sports Legends?'

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ted, what are you doing here?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: You...you shouldn't have come. I don't have time now.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes, I know. Things used to be different. I remember when we first met. It was during the war.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: We laughed, we talked, we danced, I never wanted it to end and I guess I still don't. But enough about me. I hope this hasn't been boring for you.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: It's just that when I start to talk about Elaine, I get so carried away -- I lose all track of time -- not unlike Oliver in 'Jesus: the Man.'

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: I happened to be passing, and I thought you might like some corfee.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: That's very nice of you. Thank you.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: Ah, won't you sit down?

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: Thank you. Cream?

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: No, thank you. I take it black. Like my men.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: Were you vacationing in Los Angeles?

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: Well, it really wasn't a vacation. You see, I'm a teacher in the New York City school system, and I was attending a seminar on visual aids to education. Are you from L.A.?

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: No. I'm from Washington, D.C. I'm a lobbyist for the Small Businessmen's Assocation.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Would you like to order dinner now?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: When can I see the cockpit, Dad?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Aw, gee whiz.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I tell you what, Joey. I'll talk to the Captain and see what I can arrange.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Gee! That'd be swell!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Would you gentlemen care to order your dinners?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: May I take your dinner order?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Oh, Ted, I never knew I could be so happy. These past few months have been wonderful. Tomorrow why don't we drive up the coast to that little seafood place and...

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: My orders came through. My squadron ships out tomorrow. I'll be leading a very important mission.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Oh, Ted, please be careful. I worry about you so much.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I love you, Elaine.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I love you.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Roger, Denver.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: We have a visitor.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: This is Captain Oveur. Mister Murdock and Mister Johnson. This is Joey Hammen.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Come on up here. You can see better.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Joey, here's something we give our special visitors. Would you like to have it?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Thank you. Thanks a lot!

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Have you ever been in a cockpit before?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: No, sir. I've never been up in a plane before.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Have you ever seen a grown man naked?

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Do you want me to check the weather, Clarence?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: No, why don't you take care ot it?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: We'd better get back now.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Joey can stay up here for a while if he'd like to.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Could I?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Okay, if you don't get in the way.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Flight two-zero-niner to Denver radio. Climbing to cruise at forty-two thousand. Will report again over Lincoln. Over and out.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I know you. You're Kareem Abdul Jabbar. You play basketball for the Los Angeles Lakers!

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: I'm sorry, son, but you must have me confused with someone else. My name is Roger Murdock. I'm the co-pilot.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Ah, Victor, why don't you get the coordinates on the altitude vector and find out the ratio of direct velocity over engine speed?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: You are Kareem. I've seen you play. My Dad's got season tickets!

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: I think you should go back to your seat now, Joey. Right, Clarence?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: No, he's not bothering anyone. Let him stay up here.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: All right. But just remember, my name is Roger Murdock.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: I'm an airline pilot.  Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: ...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: ...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: The hell I don't! I'm out there busting my buns every night.

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Listen, kid, I've been hearing that crap ever since I was at UCLA. Tell your old man to drag Unseld and Lanier up and down the court for forty-eight minutes.  Ah...Denver Control, this is Flight two- zero-niner continuing on a heading two- niner-niner...niner, ah...niner...niner.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Elaine, just hear me out. I know things haven't been right for a long time. But it will be different...like it was in the beginning. Remember?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I remember everything. All I have are memories.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Mostly I remember...the nights when we were together. I remember how you used to hold me...and how I used to sit on your face and wriggle...and then afterwards how we'd watch until the sun came up. When it did, it was almost like...like each new day was created...only for us.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: That's the way I've always wanted it to be, Elaine.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: But it won't be. Not as long as you insist on living in the past!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: You got a telegram from headquarters today.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Headquarters!? What is it?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It's a big building where the generals meet. But that's not important right now. They've cleared you of any blame for what happened on that raid. Isn't that good news?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Is it? Because of my mistake six men didn't return from that raid.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Seven. Lieutenant Zipp died this morning. Ted, Doctor Sandler says you'll be out in a week. Isn't that wonderful?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I wish I could say the same for George Zipp.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Be patient, Ted. No one expects you to get over this immediately.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: All right. Take five.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I found a wonderful apartment for us. It's got a brick fireplace and a cute little bedroom with mirrors on the ceiling. And...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: That's Captain Geline. He thinks he's a pilot, still fighting the war.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: What's his problem?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: That's Lieutennt Hurwitz. Severe shell shock. He thinks he's Ethel Merman.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir. Would you like some coffee before we serve dinner?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: No. No thank you.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Would either of you like another cup of coffee?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Excuse me, Sister?

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: There's a little girl on board who's ill and...

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: Oh yes, I saw. Poor child.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Could I borrow your guitar? I thought I might be able to cheer her up.

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Is it all right if I talk to your daughter?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I'm Randy.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: I'm Lisa. Oh, you have a guitar!

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I thought maybe you'd like to hear a song.

Speaker: lisa
Dialogue: Oh, I'd love to.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Okay, this is one of my favorites.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'I've traveled the banks of the River Jordan, to find where it flows to the sea.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'I looked in the eyes of the cold and the hungry and saw that I was looking at me.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'And I wanted to know if life had a purpose, and what it all means in the end. In the silence I listened to the voices inside me, and they told me again and again.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'There is only one river. There is only one sea.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'And it flows through you, and it flows through me. There is only one people, we are one and the same.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'We are all one spirit, one name. We are the Father, we are the son.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: 'In the Dawn of Creation. We are one.'

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Hey, we've been waiting for you. A little bit late tonight.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Who wants to be first?

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Go ahead, Clarence, I got it.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: How's the weather?

Speaker: murdock
Dialogue: Not so good. We've got some heavy stuff ahead of us. It might get rough again unless we can climb on top. But our airspeed is holding steady at six hundred ten knots.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: That's great. By the way, Joey Hammen asked me if you would autograph this basketball.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: After the war, I just wanted to get as far away from things as possible. So Elaine and I joined the Peace Corps. We were assigned to an isolated tribe, the Molombos.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Also, Supperware products are ideal for storing leftovers to help stretch your food dollar. This two quart "Seals-M-Rite" container with a special "Close-M-Tite" lid keeps hotdog buns fresh for days and prevents sugared cereals from sticking.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Meat and dairy products are protected against unwanted refrigerator odors when sealed in this non-slip pastel colored "Freez-o-leer".

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I think they're getting the hang of it! When we re-enlist I'll teach them baseball!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ted, I don't want to stay here. It's time for us to go back home -- to the plans we made before the war.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: A lot of people made plans before the war. Like George Zipp.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: We did come back to the States. I tried a number of jobs...Well, I could go on for hours, but I'd probably start to bore you.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: You know, I really couldn't blame Elaine. She wanted a career. I was offered a job at Boeing but I couldn't bring myself to take it...

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Oh, I can't stand it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: My, stomach. I haven't felt this awful since we saw that Lina Wertmuller film.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I'll see if I can find some Dramamine.

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: OOOOOO.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Captain, one of the women passengers is very sick.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Airsick?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I think so, but I've never seen it so acute.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Find out if there's a doctor on board, as quietly as you can.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Joey, have you ever been in a Turkish prison?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I'm sorry I had to wake you. I'm just looking for a doctor. There's nothing to worry about.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Sir. Excuse me, sir. I'm sorry to have to wake you. Are you a doctor?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: We have some passengers who are very sick. Could you come and take a look at them?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: A hospital? What is it?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Victor, we're running into a heavy storm, can you...

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Victor! Roger, take over!

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: I can't tell.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: No. I mean I'm just not sure.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Well...not for another two hours.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: No, I mean we can't land for another two hours. Fog has closed down everything this side of the mountains. We've got to go through to Chicago!

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Get him out of there!

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: What is it, Doctor? What's happening?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Well, we had a choice. Steak or fish.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: He had fish.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: We have two more sick people, and the rest of the passengers are worried.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: I'll take care of the passengers. Elaine, find out what the two sick people had for dinner.  This is Captain Oveur speaking.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Meanwhile, relax and enjoy the rest of your flight. Okay? Okay!

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: That should do it.

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Chicago, this is flight two-zero-niner. We're in trouble.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: We read you. Stand by, two-zero-niner.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing: do you know what he had for dinner?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Oh, it's nothing to be alarmed about. We'll get back to you very quickly.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Doctor Rumack, Mister Hammen ate fish. And Randy says there are five more cases, and they ate fish, too.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: He had fish, too.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Just how serious is it, doctor?

Speaker: oveur
Dialogue: Turn...on...automatic pilot.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Uh, automatic pilot...automatic pilot?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: There it is!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: This is Elaine Dickinson. I'm the stewardess. Captain Oveur is passed out on the floor, and we've lost the co-pilot and navigator, too. We're in terrible trouble. Over.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Hi, Steve!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, it is. Over.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I'm standing over Oveur. Over.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: How about Sal Mineo?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Three hundred twenty miles per hour.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Thirty-five thousand feet.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No, wait. Now it says thirty-four thousand feet. It's dropping! It's dropping fast! Why is it doing that?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Oh, my God! The automatic pilot! It's deflating!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Okay, but please hurry! We're dropping fast!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, I can see it.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No. No one that I know of.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: Hello, I'm Paul Carey from the airline. I'm here to pick up Captain Kramer.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: Well, to tell the truth, they really didn't fill me in on many of the details. Just told me to pick up Captain Kramer.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: Yeah, something like that, but as I say, they didn't have time to tell me very much.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: Well...the airline business...does have... its moments...

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: ...but after...awhile...you begin to...  ...get used to it.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: I'm...in a...argh...navigator training program.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: It's unbelievable! How many times have I warned those people about food inspection?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: The airport management, the F.A.A., and the airlines, they're all cheats and liars! All right, let's get out of here.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Sorry to bother you. We were just looking for someone with flying experience.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: You see, the day we left the village it was raining, so we had to take a special jeep to the main road...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: In fact, we were lucky to even get a jeep since just the day before the only one we had broke down -- it had a bad axle...

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir. There's been a little problem in the cockpit and I was wondering...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: The cockpit? What is it?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: It's the little room at the front of the plane where the pilots sit. But that's not important right now. The first officer is ill and the Captain would like someone with flying experience to help him with the radio. Do you know anything about planes?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Well, I flew in the war, but that was a long time ago. I wouldn't know anything about it.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Would you go up, please?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Would ya like a little whiskey, ma'am?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: The stewardess said...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Both pilots!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Surely you can't be serious.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Well, I flew single-engine fighters in the Air Force, but this plane has four engines. It's an entirely different kind of flying...all together!!!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Besides, I haven't touched any kind of plane in six years.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Would anyone care for a roll and coffee?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: No, we can't do that; the risk of a flameout is too great. Keep him 24,000. No, feet!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: One of the passengers is going to land that plane.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: Is that possible?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Possible, but it's a hundred to one shot. Thousand to one. I know this guy.

Speaker: carey
Dialogue: You do? Who is it?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: His name is Ted Striker. I flew with him during the war. And that won't make my job any easier tonight.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Ted Striker was a crack flight leader up to a point. But he was one of those men who, well, let's just say he felt too much inside. Maybe you know the kind.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: It takes a certain type to perform under pressure. Striker didn't have it.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Ate his heart out over every name on the casualty lists. The upshot of it is that he went all to pieces on one particular mission. Let's just hope it doesn't happen again tonight.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Let's see, altitude twenty-four thousand feet, level flight, air speed four hundred sixty knots, course zero niner zero, trim, mixture, landing gear, balance.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ted! What are you doing? You can't fly this plane!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: That's what I've been trying to tell these people.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Let's see. Those are the flaps, that's the thrust, this must turn on the landing lights.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Mayday!

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: It's the Russian New Year! We'll have a parade! They'll serve hot hors d'oeuvres!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yeah, I was just trying out the landing lights.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Calm down. Get hold of yourself!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stewardess, let me handle this.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Get hold of yourself! Get hold of yourself!

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: Doctor, you're wanted on the phone.

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: Everything will be all right. Please get hold of yourself.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right, Steve, let's face a few facts.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: As you know, I flew with this man, Striker, during the war. He'll have enough on his mind without remembering those days when -- well, when things weren't so good.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Let me tell you something, Steve. Striker was a top-notch squadron leader -- a long time ago...

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: ...but my feeling is that when the going gets rough upstairs tonight, Ted Striker's gonna fold up.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Very well then. Put Striker on the speaker.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, Striker, this is Captain Rex Kramer speaking.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes, Captain Kramer. Read you loud and clear.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right. It's obvious you remember me.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: So what do you say you and I just forget about everything except what we have to do now?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: You and I are going to bring this plane in together.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Before we start, I'd like to say something. I know that right now things must look pretty rough up there.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: But if you do what I tell you, when I tell you to do it, there's no reason you can't bring that plane in.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Let's not kid each other, Kramer. You know I've never flown a bucket like this. I'm going to need all the luck there is.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Stand by, Striker.  All right, Striker, have you ever flown a multi-engine plane before?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Shit!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right, Striker, now you listen to me and you listen close. Flying is no different than riding a bicycle...it just happens to be a lot harder to put baseball cards in the spokes. Now, if you just follow my instructions...

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: First, I want you to familiarize yourself with the controls. Later we'll run through the landing procedure.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right. Now I'd like you to disengage the automatic pilot. But watch any violent movement of the controls, like you used to make in Spitfires and Phantoms.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Okay, I'm going to unlock the automatic pilot.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes! The stewardess is here with me!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: The radio's all yours now. And keep an eye on that number three engine. It's running a little hot.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Rain.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: And a little ice.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: And a little ice!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: It's a damn good thing he doesn't know how much I hate his guts.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It's a damn good thing you don't know how much he hates your guts.

Speaker: black dude
Dialogue: Oooooooh.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Can I get something for you?

Speaker: black dude
Dialogue: Cain fo' gwine sho fi cun for.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I don't understand.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Tell him to relax and I'll be back as quickly as I can with some medicine.

Speaker: black dude
Dialogue: Shi man I ain neba mo fo gwine ain.

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: '...I sit by the telephone for hours. I love when men send me flowers. I enjoy being a girl.'

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How ya doing, honey?

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Oh Jack, I'm so warm. I'm burning up.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: After my wife died, I felt like a fifth wheel. You know, so many years being with one person -- a very wonderful person -- makes you always think of yourself as part of a pair...When Ethel passed away, I was lost. I couldn't function socially and I couldn't function in business.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: Well, after a thing like that you wouldn't be expected to.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: But I think it's time we stopped talking about me. A woman like you -- why haven't you ever married?

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: Well, I'm afraid that's a question that's all too easy to answer.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: I know the answer -- Career. A smart woman like you became so involved in your work, you didn't have time for marriage.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: I wish I could fool myself into believing that that's the reason. The truth of the matter is, nobody ever asked me.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: You know, here we are having coffee together, and discussing education and business and economy...and we don't even know each other's names...full names I mean.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: Mine's Eleanor. Eleanor Schiff.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: That's a lovely name. Mine's Milton...Milt Ettenhenim. But my friends call me 'Bubbles.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Would you care for a soft drink?

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: This? Why, I could make a hat or a broach...

Speaker: horse
Dialogue: Did you finish? Was I good?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Would you care for another drink?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Doctor Rumack says the sick people are getting worse and we're running out of time.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's going on? We have a right to know the truth!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Chicago, the passengers are beginning to panic. When do we start down?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Not just yet, we'll have you in radar range any second now.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: I don't understand it. He should have been in range ten minutes ago.

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: About two more minutes, Chief.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: That's impossible. They're on instruments!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: This is gonna be a real sweat.  Gunderson, let me know when you get anything.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Would you like half of my provolone and roast beef?

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: I think Florence Henderson knows about it!

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: What are the chances of returning something to Montgomery Ward the week after Christmas?

Speaker: newscaster
Dialogue: Striken Airliner Approaches Chicago!

Speaker: jack kilpatrick
Dialogue: Shana, they bought their tickets, they knew what they were getting into. I say, let 'em crash!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes, everything they've got. How are the passengers doing?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Surely there must be something you can do.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, I'm not dead.

Speaker: sister angelina
Dialogue: 'What you want, Baby I got, What you need, You know I got it. All I'm askin' for Is a little respect When you come home.'

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Doctor Rumack, I'm scared. I've never been so scared. And besides, I'm twenty-six and I'm not married.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: Oh boy, oh boy, oh boy.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: No, the risk of fire is too great. If she starts burning, you write off all those people who can't get out of there on their own power.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: No. A belly landing isn't all that simple. It takes a good pilot to keep from smearin' himself all over the runway.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: His only shot's with the wheels down. I've seen foam tear a man's guts out.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: That's a risk we'll just have to take.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Rats! I've lost number three.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: What happened, Ted? What went wrong?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Oil pressure. I forgot to check the oil pressure. When Kramer hears about this, the shit's gonna hit the fan.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: I told him to watch that oil temperature. What the hell's he doing up there?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, that plane can't land itself! It takes a pilot who can handle pressure.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: It happened to Barbara Stanwyck!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: He's right. I can't take the pressure. I was crazy to think I could land this plane.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: But Ted, you're the only...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I don't care. I just don't have what it takes. They'd be better off with someone who'd never flown before.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: And Liz Taylor is getting larger!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right, but let's wait until they reach the control area.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I know what you're going to say, so save your breath.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: George Zipp said that?

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Excuse me, Doc, I've got a plane to land.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I'll take it, Elaine.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Listen to me, Kramer. Doctor Rumack says the sick people are in critical condition and every minute counts. We've got to land now!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: No dice, Chicago. I'm giving the orders, and we're coming in...I guess the foot's on the other hand now, isn't it, Kramer?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: I know. I know. But it's his ship now, his command; he's in charge, he's the boss, the head man, the top dog, the big cheese, the head honcho...

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: 'Passengers Certain to Die?!?!?!?!?!'

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: There's a sale at Penny's!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: You, Neubauer. You, Macias.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Me John. Big tree.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Wagon train comes three, maybe four day away.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Stand by, Striker. I'm going to the tower. And good luck.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: The tower! Oh! Rapunzel! Rapunzel!

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: In a moment we'll ask you to assume crash positions. Your life jackets are located under your seat.

Speaker: striped controller
Dialogue: We're all ready, sir.

Speaker: striped controller
Dialogue: Captain McCroskey, this is Captain Roberts. Captain Kramer, this is Captain Colosimo. Captain Hinshaw, Captain Gatz. Captain Kramer, Captain Gatz. Captain Hinshaw, Captain Roberts.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right. Colosimo, you'll work the relay. Roberts, double check all air traffic within five miles.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: And get that finger out of your ear. You don't know where that finger's been! Gunderson?

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: Yes, Captain?

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Did you decide on a runway yet?

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: Runway niner. It's the longest, and directly into the wind.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: And the foliage looks so pretty this time of year.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, you're going to have to work fast. After this message, do not acknowledge any transmission unless you want to ask a question. Do you understand? Striker, Striker, do you read me?

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Just like Gerald Ford!

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Where did you get that dress? It's an eye- sore!

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: Eight miles. Turn right to heading zero eight niner.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: You are now eight miles from the airport. Turn right to a heading of zero eight niner, throttle back slightly and begin to lose altitude to fifteen hundred feet.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Steve, I want every light you can get poured on that field.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Tower to all emergency vehicles. Runway is niner.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Civilian equipment, number three.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: It's a twister! It's a twister! Toto!... Auntie Em!

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: It won't be long now. Try not to worry.

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: He's all over the place! Nine hundred feet up to thirteen hundred feet! What an asshole!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Watch your altitude, Striker. It's too erratic. You can't come straight in. You've got enough fuel left for two hours flying. You've got to stay up there 'til we get a break in the weather.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: I'll take it, Elaine.  Listen, Kramer, I'm coming in. Do you hear me? I'm coming in right now! We have people up here who will die in less than an hour, never mind two. I may bend your precious airplane, but I'll get it down! Now get on with the landing check. I'm putting the gear down now.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Mr. Striker, the passengers are ready.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Thank you, Randy. You better leave sweetheart. You might get hurt in here.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ted...

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I wanted you to know -- now -- I'm very proud.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Tell them the gear is down and we're ready to land.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: The gear is down.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: Well, I'll give him another twenty minutes, but that's it.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: I'm sure we'll both make it...but just in case one of us...well, is there a message you'd like me to give someone?

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: No. I'm all alone.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: Just in case I don't have a chance to say goodbye, I want you to know that I haven't spent so many pleasant hours for many years.

Speaker: bernice
Dialogue: That's a very nice compliment, and I'd like to say that...you've done the same for me.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Now, Striker...hold your present heading, put down full flap, bring your air speed back to a hundred and thirty-five, then I want you to take hold of the throttle...

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: And stick it in your ear.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: And stick it in your ear.

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: I'll be good, I will, I will.

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: Captain, he's dropping off fast. Almost seven hundred.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, get back to a thousand feet!

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: He's below seven hundred now and he's still going down! 675! 650! 625! 600!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, you're coming in too low! What's your altitude?

Speaker: gunderson
Dialogue: He's right on the heading.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right, he's on final now! Put out all runway lights except niner.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Turn on your landing lights, Striker. It's the switch above your right knee.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: All right, now just listen carefully. You should be able to see the runway at three hundred feet.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Aim to touchdown a third of the way along. There's a slight crosswind from the right, so be ready for it.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: If you land too fast, use your emergency brakes. The red handle is right in front of you.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: If that doesn't stop you...

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: If that doesn't stop you, cut the four ignition switches over the co-pilot's head.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: See them, Elaine?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Do you see us now? You should be able to see the field now.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Yeah -- too quiet.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, you're coming in too fast!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Sound your alarm bell now.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: All right, now, everybody get in crash positions.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Airspeed one twenty-five, one thirty...

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Just kidding!

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: ...one thirty-five, one forty.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Striker, now listen to me. You're coming down too fast!

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: It's stuck. It won't move!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Bring it down! Easy!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Remember your brakes and switches! Get ready to flare it out! You're coming in too fast! Watch your speed!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: You're coming in too hot! Put down full flaps! Watch your nose!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Now ease her down! Down!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Lift the nose! Throttle back!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: The brake! Pull the red handle!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Hold her steady, hold her steady!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Pull a lever!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Push a button!

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: You're too low! You're too low!

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Can we help arrange hotel accommodations or a rent-a-car during your stay in Chicago?

Speaker: hinshaw
Dialogue: Wheel me to the West Wing. I wish to view the Degas.

Speaker: striker
Dialogue: Yeah, we're okay.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: Ted, that was probably the lousiest landing in the history of this airport. But there are some of us here...

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Hurry now. Please be careful.

Speaker: kramer
Dialogue: ...Lonliness, that's the bottom line. I was never happy as a child. Christmas, Ted, what does it mean to you? For me, it was a living hell. Do you know what it's like to fall in the mud and get kicked? In the head? By an iron boot? Of course you don't. No one does. That never happens. Sorry, Ted. Dumb question. Strike that.
